title: fix: safer dump of `vectors` in the HuggingFace Hub
body:
# Description

This PR solves an issue that was happening (and is still happening) related to the naming we're using for the columns in the HuggingFace Hub dataset, as we're exporting each of the fields and responses using their names in Argilla, and appending `-suggestion` or whatever feels necessary, but we can run into conflicts in any `field` is name as any other `question`, named `metadata` or named `external_id`, as well as the other way around for `question`.

So on, this PR fixes that for the upcoming `vectors`, as those are usually named after the field that those refer to, so instead of dumping those under the same name, we're dumping a Python dict in a column named `vectors` where each key-value pair is a vector name and its value. Similarly to what was done previously for the former Argilla datasets.

**Type of change**

- [x] Bug fix (non-breaking change which fixes an issue)

**How Has This Been Tested**

- [x] Add integration tests for duplicated name on `vectors_settings` for a given vector and ensured that it's dumped and restored properly

title: fix: Dump dataset config from json serialization
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

Using the `use_enum_values = True` works only at the root level. We should review all sub-models used by the `DatasetConfig` class to properly serialize enums. 

As a simple (but not efficient) workaround, a double serialization-deserialization using json is applied. This will ensure that extra tags are not serialized as part of the resultant file. 

Also, the `safe_dump` function is used, which prevents and raises errors when a non-basic tags is detected.

body:
If this snippet is accessed in the Train Reward Tutorial without actually labelling data in Argilla, we get an index out of range error.

```
dataset = feedback_dataset.prepare_for_training(framework="trl", task=task)
dataset
```

With few lines of code, we can prevent this behaviour in all tutorials that use this mechanic and guide the user to go to Argilla and annotate.

title: docs: Fixing List Index out of range in Train Reward tutorial
body:
Closes #4164

- [X] Documentation update

By protecting the code to accessing non-annotated records, we obtain a dataset like:


```
dataset = feedback_dataset.prepare_for_training(framework="trl", task=task)
dataset
```

```
[(2, 1)]
[(1, 1)]
[(2, 1)]
[(2, 1)]
[(1, 1)]
[(2, 1)]
Dataset({
    features: ['chosen', 'rejected'],
    num_rows: 6
})
```

And training works afterwards. Tell me if you want me to do something more sophisticated to maybe avoid the case in which no record is annotated.

body: ## Which page or section is this issue related to? The idea is to have runnable end2end examples of basic real-life examples for the different `task-templates`, where we will initially focus on the most common task `text-classification`. Things to keep in mind: - they need to be executable individually but may require previous examples to be run by referencing them - they need to be aligned with the [practical guides](https://docs.argilla.io/en/latest/practical_guides/practical_guides.html) to ensure maintainability - it might be nice to add an [optional telemetry module](https://haystack.deepset.ai/tutorials/14_query_classifier) to see the number of usages for tutorials. - ideally, an updated version of these tutorial datasets should be available on the Hugging Face hub as imports ```[tasklist] ### Tasks - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4189 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4198 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4179 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4183 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4199 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4181 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4182 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4185 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4184 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4186 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4187 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4220 - [ ] https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4280 ```

title: feat: add `metrics` module
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR introduces a new module `argilla.client.feedback.metrics` to compute different metrics for a `FeedbackDataset`:

`argilla.client.feedback.metrics.annotator_metrics`
- [ ] For a given user, to compare its responses against the suggestions that were given. Depending on the type of question:
  - [x] `LabelQuestion`
  - [ ] `MultiLabelQuestion`
  - [x] `RatingQuestion`
  - [ ] `RankingQuestion`
  - [x] `TextQuestion`

   Example for a `FeedbackDataset` with 3 annotators:

   ```python
   dataset = FeedbackDataset(...)
   metric = AnnotatorMetric(dataset, "question-name")
   metrics_report = metric.compute(["gleu"])
   # >>> metrics_report
   # {'00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000001': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.16666666666666666)], 
   # '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000002': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.25)],    
   # '00000000-0000-0000-0000-000000000003': [AnnotatorMetricResult(metric_name='gleu', result=0.16666666666666666)]}
   # or a list of metrics
   metrics_report = metric.compute(["accuracy", "confusion-matrix"])
   ```

- [ ] To compare unified responses against the suggestions.
*In progress*

- [x] `argilla.client.feedback.metrics.agreement_metrics`


   ```python
   dataset = FeedbackDataset(...)
   metric = AgreementMetric(dataset, "question-name")
   metrics_report = metric.compute("alpha")
   # >>> metrics_report
   # [AgreementMetric(metric_name='alpha', result=0.89)]
   ```

Closes #4034

title: [BUG] ArgillaTrainer returns error with transformers while training

labels.name: type: bug
labels.description: Indicates an unexpected problem or unintended behavior

labels.name: area: api
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Fast API server or REST endpoints

labels.name: team: ml

body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
When I want to do QA with ArgillaTrainer with a dataset annotated on Argilla and pulled, the trainer returns with an error after one epoch. The problem is with the `compute_metrics_question_answering` method inside transformers script. There seems to be a problem with the compute_metrics function that is not compatible with the dataset used.

**Stacktrace and Code to create the bug**
```python
annotated_dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset.from_argilla("annotated_dataset", workspace="argilla")
task = TrainingTask.for_question_answering(
    question=annotated_dataset.field_by_name("question"),
    context=annotated_dataset.field_by_name("context"),
    answer=annotated_dataset.question_by_name("answer"),
)
trainer = ArgillaTrainer(
    dataset=annotated_dataset,
    task=task,
    framework="transformers",
    train_size=0.7,
)

trainer.train(output_dir="qa_model")
```

│   3358 │   │   │   else:                                                                         │
│ ❱ 3359 │   │   │   │   metrics = self.compute_metrics(EvalPrediction(predictions=all_preds, lab  │
│   3360 │   │   else:                                                                             │

│   3362                                                                                           │

title: Add new `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search` endpoint with vector search support for admin (SDK) operations
body:
# Description

This PR add the following changes:
* Handler function `search_dataset_records` has been renamed to `search_current_user_dataset_records`.
* Add a new `POST /api/v1/datasets/{dataset_id}/records/search` endpoint without current user context so it can be used to search for records by owners and admin and getting responses from all users.
* Add a new `search_records_with_all_responses` method for dataset policies v1 used by the new endpoint.
* Update SDK API to use this new endpoint instead of the old one with current user context.
* Some small refactors:
  * Improve order on some policies functions.
  * Fix problem with `limit` query param not including a lower limit of 1.
  * Fix problem with `limit` query param using `lte` inexistent parameter (instead of the right one `le`).

I'm adding as well a new test type where we focus in testing one specific endpoint. This test includes a class with two important aspects:
* A instance method `url` defining the `url` that is used for all the tests.
* Simple and isolated tests that don't use external helper functions.

Closes #4114

title: feat: List record with `include` vectors parameter
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

This PR supports fetching records with vectors from Python SDK. A new argument is provided in `from_argilla` method to provide which vectors must be downloaded with records (None by default). Users can set this argument to `all` to download all vectors found in the records.

I also the relationship in the `Vector` ORM class to load `vector_settings` has been changed to load them by default. Otherwise, a massive `awaitable_attrs` must be applied in order to create the vector dictionary without getting the lovely error `sqlalchemy.exc.MissingGreenlet: greenlet_spawn has not been called;`

Please, @gabrielmbmb take a look into it, and let's discuss if we can optimize this a bit. 

Closes https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/issues/4102

import argilla as rg

title: [BUG] Shift + Space scrolls up the page when annotating, leading to bad annotation experience
body:
<!--  Ask David for help you to contribute https://calendly.com/argilla-office-hours/30min or feel free to submit a pull request straight away: https://github.com/argilla-io/argilla/pulls or  -->

**Describe the bug**
When annotating a dataset (e.g. by writing in the annotation box), shift + space scrolls up the page, which leads to bad user experience while annotating.

This happens more often for fast-typing users and when annotating data that requires special characters like `{`, `[`, etc.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Go to any existing Text2Text dataset record in the Argilla UI
2. Click on a text box to start annotating (writing or modifying the ground truth)
3. Press Shift + Space
4. Scroll up happens

**Expected behavior**
No scroll up happens.

**Screenshots**
N/A

**Environment (please complete the following information):**
Argilla server version is `1.14`

title: [FEATURE] Improve `responses` logging from the Python client

labels.name: type: enhancement
labels.description: Indicates new feature requests

labels.name: team: ml
labels.description: Indicates that the issue or pull request is owned by the Machine Learning (ML) team

labels.name: area: python sdk
labels.description: Indicates that an issue or pull request is related to the Python SDK

body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**

As of now, it's pretty tedious to log `responses` from a `FeedbackRecord` from the Python client, as the `responses` is a dict with a lot of nested dicts, which makes it hard to define those manually.

Additionally, we could also rename it from `ResponseSchema` to `RecordResponse`, `FeedbackResponse`, or something similar, so that the naming is more clear to the users; as well as with the `SuggestionSchema` to `RecordSuggestion`, `FeedbackSuggestion`, or something similar.

**Describe the solution you'd like**

We should be able to define the following (or similar):

```python
import argilla as rg

dataset = rg.FeedbackDataset(fields=[rg.TextField(name="text-field")], questions=[rg.TextQuestion(name="text-question")])

dataset.add_records([
    rg.FeedbackRecord(
        fields={"text-field": "This is a text"},
        responses=[rg.RecordResponse(name="text-question", value="This is a response")],
    ])
```

title: fix: Support combining knn and filtering with OpenSearch
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

For OpenSearch engines, including boolean filters as part of the `knn` filter may return query phase errors if the response fields are not found in documents for the requested user (`responses.username.status = ...`). This is something that is not happening with Elasticsearch.

So, this PR fixes this by setting those query filters as a `post_filter` in the query. (This will potentially return less record than expected `k`, but it will be something to assume when using the OpenSearch engine.

title: chore: Upgrade minimal OpenSearch version to 2.6.0
body:
<!-- Thanks for your contribution! As part of our Community Growers initiative 🌱, we're donating Justdiggit bunds in your name to reforest sub-Saharan Africa. To claim your Community Growers certificate, please contact David Berenstein in our Slack community or fill in this form https://tally.so/r/n9XrxK once your PR has been merged. -->

# Description

Doing some tests with OpenSearch 2.5 I realized some cases where similarity search fails when adding as part of the `knn` filter an existing field clause (for user responses). This is documented and fixed in the Lucene 9.5.0 version (See here: https://github.com/apache/lucene/pull/12072). So the minimal required OpenSearch version must use the Lucene 9.5.0, which is 2.6.0.

Using versions under  2.6.0 an error `"failed to create query: Rewrite first"` using similarity search can be potentially raised.
